L2_gloss: A sort of early morning soapbox, where elders air their opinions and grievances as the community gathers around the campfire.
An edible mushroom; horse dung fungus, Bohemian truffle, Pisolithus tinctorius
snake, in particular the carpet snake

wild, untamed
Papa nyanga inuṟa.This dog is wild.
desert fuchsia, used for bush medicine

and (switching)
Watingku maḻu nyangu ka wirtjapakaṉu.The man saw the kangaroo and the kangaroo ran away.
Torresian crow, Australian crow, Corvus orru

water
Tjiḻpingku nyinara kapi tjikinu.The old man sat drinking water.
An adhesive gum made from spinifex or mulga.

to hear
Ngayulu palunya wangka kulinu. ― I heard her voice.

woman
Kungka tjuṯangku ngurangka nyinara tii tjikinu.The women sat at camp drinking tea.
to turn bad, to hate, to dislike, to resent, (of a
This term needs a translation to English. Please help out and add a translation, then remove the text {{rfdef}}.
now, at the present time, nowadays
at, on, in, near, with, etc. for proper nouns that end with a vowel. The equivalent of -ngka, and -ta.
food (especially non-meat food; sometimes used for food in general)
money, mani wiyangku ― free of charge
wooden bowl used to carry water
goanna, in particular the sand goanna
to get an itchy feeling in one's nose
the two of us (accusative case, object of the sentence)
my, for me, mine; possessive/purposive form of ngayulu
The perentie, a large goanna species.

tame
Papa nyara ngultju.That dog is tame.

this
Aṉanguku ngura nyangatja.
This is Aṉangu land.

(demonstrative) that over there
Kanyaḻa nyara ngalkuṉi.That euro over there is eating.
you (singular, accusative case, object of sentence)
you two (accusative case, object of sentence)
Epenthetic suffix added when the word would otherwise end in a consonant

(demonstrative) that, there
Watingku pala tii tjikini. ― That man is drinking tea.

accusative form of paluṟu; him, her, it
Nyaaku nyuntu palunya patjaṉu?What did you hit him for?
to make, to repair, to fix, to mend

dog
Papangku nyinara kuka ngalkuṉu. ― The dog sat eating meat.
Synonym: tjiṯutja
food gathering dish (traditionally used by women; along with a wana it is used to symbolise women)
the two of them, those two (accusative, object of sentence)

big
Papa puḻkangku ngayunya patjaṉu.A big dog bit me.

very
Paluṟu pika puḻka.He is very sick.

unsuccessfully, in vain
2010, Re-awakening Languages: Theory and Practice in the Revitalisation of Australia's Indigenous Languages, Sydney University Press, 2010, p. 85:
Mungaṯu nyangangku katjangku wangkangu, Ngunytjimalu wangkangu, "Maḻu anytjapiri mantjila", ka tjitji kutju kunyu puṯu kuliningi, "Nyaa, nyaa?" Puṯu alatjitu kuliningi anytjapiri.
Recently this person's son was saying, Ngunytjima was saying, "Get some whole kangaroo", and that child [to whom he was speaking] apparently couldn't understand [literally "unsuccessfully understood"], [saying] "What, what?" He couldn't understand anytjapiri at all.
to stitch the end of clothing (hem)
goanna, in particular the sand goanna

child
Lirungku tjitji patjaṉu.A snake bit the child.
Milky Way (band of stars), a type of makeshift ladder
A word relating to traditional lore, laws and songlines
Uluru, Ayers Rock (a large rock formation in central
digging stick for gathering food (traditionally used by women; along with a piti it symbolises women)
young kangaroo or wallaroo that is still with its mother but no longer in the pouch
man, particularly one who has been initiated
Adverb of negation: no, not, none
